exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Victory hangs in the summer air like the scent of orange blossoms. Three days ago, René of Anjou's army surrendered at Aversa—a desperate cavalry charge broken against Castilian steel, followed by French soldiers weeping with relief as they laid down their arms. Yesterday, Queen Joanna II named Alfonso V her heir before the assembled nobility of Naples. The Calabrian barons knelt; the French claimant departed with his honor intact but his ambitions extinguished. The Kingdom of Naples is secure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Now Juan finds himself in that strange pause between crises—the brief calm that medieval kings learn to distrust. Lucia, six months heavy with child, rests at the Palazzo Caracciolo, her sharp tongue only slightly dulled by the summer heat. The 200 Military Order soldiers who remain with Juan wait for their next purpose. Alfonso V, newly confirmed as Joanna's heir, is already turning his considerable energy toward the administrative work of claiming his prize.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And somewhere across the Adriatic, Sultan Murad II considers a Castilian king's unprecedented request for a meeting. The Sultan's reply—cautious engagement, agreeing that a meeting 'may be possible'—was dispatched weeks ago. Intermediaries have been discussed. Conditions remain to be negotiated. That response should arrive any day now, if it hasn't already reached the port.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning light streams through the windows as Naples stirs outside—a city suddenly certain of its future after months of siege and uncertainty. Juan seeks out Alfonso to discuss the situation.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I go to Alfonso and discuss the situation with him.

encounters.recap: With Naples secured after René of Anjou's surrender and Alfonso V confirmed as heir, Juan finds himself in a brief calm between crises. As the Sultan's reply regarding a potential meeting is expected to arrive, Juan seeks out Alfonso to discuss their current strategic situation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning light streams through the windows of whatever chamber Juan occupies. Naples stirs outside—a city suddenly certain of its future after months of siege and uncertainty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Alfonso, I have been declared defensor and now that you have accepted the position as my regent should I die, I was hoping we could now formally bind our kingdoms together. As you know I am in a fight with the Ottomans. We are not at war right now but it is only a matter of time. I have committed Castille to this fight and I will name Castille and Leon part of the Defensor arrangements. I will command the defense and offensive military actions across the Byzantine empire, Castille and Leon. I was hoping to add Aragon and Naples to that list. Of course only with your permission. But since we are essentially each other's heir and the situation in Constantinople grants us enormous opportunity if we work together, I was hoping you would at least consider it. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso nods slowly but his expression is guarded. His face reflects careful consideration of Juan's proposal, weighing the implications.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The principle is sound. We are one house, one purpose. But 'command' is a heavy word between kings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso proposes a lesser arrangement: formal coordination and consultation, mutual defense obligations, joint war councils—but stops short of placing Aragonese forces under Castilian command. He wants partnership, not hierarchy.

roll.outcome: Cautious Negotiation: Alfonso accepts the concept but proposes partnership rather than hierarchy. He wants formal coordination and joint war councils, but not unified command.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes formally binding Castile, Aragón, and Naples under the Defensor arrangements with unified military command against the Ottomans. Alfonso accepts the principle but negotiates for partnership rather than subordination, preferring coordination and joint councils over unified command.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning finds Alfonso in the smaller council chamber of Castel Nuovo—the room he has already begun to think of as his, though Queen Joanna still breathes in her apartments above. Maps of southern Italy cover the table, marked with the positions of Calabrian lords whose loyalty remains to be tested. A half-eaten breakfast sits forgotten beside correspondence bearing seals from Barcelona, Valencia, Sicily.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He looks up as Juan enters, and his face transforms—genuine warmth, the smile of a man who owes everything to the man before him. He rises, clasps Juan's arm in the warrior's grip they have shared since the night march to Aversa.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Juan. Sit, please. Wine? It's Sicilian—not as good as Castilian, I'm told, though I've never believed that particular claim.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He listens as Juan speaks of the Defensor arrangements, of binding the kingdoms together, of unified command for the defense of Constantinople and the inevitable conflict with the Ottomans. His expression shifts as Juan continues—not hostile, but thoughtful. Guarded. The warmth remains, but something else enters his eyes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When Juan finishes, Alfonso is silent for a long moment. He turns to the window, looking out over the bay where Castilian and Aragonese ships ride at anchor together.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You have done everything for me. Everything. The florins when I needed them. The fleet. The diplomacy. Fifteen thousand men who marched through the night and broke René's army while I watched from walls I could not leave. I knelt and swore before God to be father to your children and guardian to your kingdoms. I meant every word. I still mean them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the table, his fingers tracing the coastline of southern Italy on the map.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The principle is sound. We are one house, one purpose—I believe that. But... 'Command' is a heavy word between kings, Juan. Even between brothers.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: If I place Aragón and Naples under Castilian command for crusading purposes—even with my full consent, even with joy in my heart—what do my nobles see? What does the Pope see? What does history record? They see the Crown of Aragón subordinated to Castile. They see a king who won his kingdom with another king's army and then... surrendered his sovereignty in gratitude.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I am not refusing. I am not even reluctant in my heart. But I have nobles in Barcelona who have never forgiven my Italian obsessions. I have Sicilian barons who fear absorption into a greater power. I have a kingdom I have not yet actually held—Joanna lives, and until she dies and I am crowned, I am heir, not king. And these Calabrian lords who knelt two days ago? Half of them supported René. They are watching to see what kind of king I will be. If my first act is to place my crown beneath another...

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: What I can offer—what I want to offer—is this: formal coordination. Joint war councils where we plan together as equals. Mutual defense obligations—an attack on Constantinople is an attack on all three kingdoms. Shared intelligence, shared costs, shared purpose. But when Aragonese soldiers march, an Aragonese commander leads them. When Neapolitan ships sail, they sail under my authority. We fight together, Juan. Not with you commanding and me following.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Is that not enough? We are already each other's heirs. We are already bound by blood and oath and gratitude beyond measure. Must we also have one crown above the other? Can we not be... partners? Two swords wielded by one purpose, rather than one sword with two handles?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course, we are partners. And we should take time to consolidate Naples the coming years. And having you crowned king will be an important step. I have spoken with your nobles in Aragon and they indeed are tired of fighting. They deserve a peace hard won.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In my experience, there are always some nobles who will test your authority. When they do, crush them. And I will help you do so should you accept my aid. I have established a system of crown marshalls in Castille who have been instrumental in exposing those who do not respect crown authority.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What is important is naval coordination in case the sultan attacks Constantinople. He will bring 100.000 men and I will have to bring an army of a size to match that. An enormous operation that requires many ships. While you consolidate your rule and give your people peace, can you lend me your fleets for transport?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso's shoulders relax visibly at Juan's words. The tension that had crept into his posture—the worry that his refusal of unified command might have wounded the relationship—drains away.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Partners. Yes. That is what we are.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Crown Marshals. Álvaro has written to me about this system—how you've brought the great houses to heel without war, through law and accountability rather than the sword. I could use such a system. The Calabrians who knelt two days ago will test me within the year. I know this. They are watching to see if the new king is weak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: When Juan turns to the matter of fleets, Alfonso's expression becomes calculating—not resistant, but practical. The merchant-prince of Barcelona considering logistics.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: One hundred thousand men. You truly believe the Sultan would commit such a force?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the map table, tracing the sea lanes from Naples to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The Aragonese fleet... at full strength, perhaps sixty galleys, twenty larger vessels. Sicily adds another thirty galleys. Naples... René's fleet is scattered or captured. Perhaps fifteen serviceable ships once we've sorted through the harbor. But crews are another matter—many fled or died during the siege.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I can lend you ships. For the defense of Constantinople, for transport of armies, for whatever you need against the Ottoman. But I need to understand the timing. When do you envision this great operation? This year? Next? Five years hence?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: If you need the fleet this autumn, I cannot give it—I must secure my coasts, show strength to the Calabrians, ensure René's remnants do not return with French reinforcements. But if you speak of next year, or the year after... Then yes. We can plan. We can coordinate. The fleet of Aragón-Naples will carry Castilian armies east when the hour comes.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Tell me what you are truly planning, Juan. Not the vision—I know the vision. But the plan. When do you expect the Sultan to move? What forces do you intend to gather? Where will they assemble?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I have learned, these past months, that you do not speak of things lightly. If you say one hundred thousand Ottomans, you have reason to believe it. Share that reason with me, and we will find a way to answer it together.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I understand your position, and I will help you secure Naples as best I can.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My strategy is to build up the strength of Constantinople the coming years. Many will settle there, I will train the army and militia. Repair the walls. When the Sultan moves in and starts a siege, I will come with as much as I can as fast as I can. The coming 2 years will be difficult to do so quickly and the sultan knows this. The city is recovering and I have not established my support network. That is why I hope that in time, Aragon and Naples will join the defensor in the war against the muslims. But we have time. The sultan cannot launch an operation immediately. That requires years of preparation from him as well. So we will see.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In five years we will be so much stronger than we are now. So until then, I will just wait and build our strength. After that, I will probably launch a campain through hungary first combined with an attack from the city to re-take the anastacian wall.

roll.outcome: Partnership, Not Hierarchy - Cautious acceptance of coordination rather than unified command

encounters.recap: Juan proposes unified command for the Defensor arrangements, but Alfonso diplomatically declines formal subordination while accepting partnership. They agree on naval coordination for future Ottoman conflicts and Alfonso's gradual integration into the Defensor alliance as equals rather than hierarchy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso listens intently, his military mind working through the implications. When Juan finishes, he nods slowly—not the nod of a man agreeing to please, but of one genuinely processing strategy.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Five years. Yes. That makes sense. The Sultan cannot conjure one hundred thousand men from nothing either. He must gather them, supply them, move them. And every year Constantinople grows stronger is a year he loses advantage.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pulls a chair closer and sits, gesturing for Juan to join him.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The Hungarian route... János Hunyadi. You have corresponded with him, yes? I have heard of this man—the voivode who actually wins against Ottoman armies. If anyone knows how to campaign through the Balkans, it is him. But Hungary is fractured. The nobles squabble while the Turk watches. Can Hunyadi deliver a unified Hungarian force, or only his own Transylvanian levies?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The Anastasian Wall... you mean to push the Sultan back from Thrace entirely. Not merely defend Constantinople, but reclaim the approaches. That is not defense, Juan. That is reconquest. That is driving the Ottoman from Europe.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso is silent for a long moment, weighing something.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: In five years, Naples will be secure. My fleet rebuilt, my nobles cowed or won. Sicily prosperous. Aragón at peace. When that day comes—when you march through Hungary and sail to Constantinople—I will be there. Not just my ships. Me. Alfonso of Aragón, fighting beside you. I wasted twelve years chasing Italian glory for pride. If God grants me the chance to spend the next twelve fighting for something that matters...

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: What of the Pope? Basel? Do they support this vision?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The pope, Basel, Poland, Hungary, the holy roman empire princes... we will have to conduct diplomacy. But I have good relations with them, God willing we will prevail. Will you grant me and my navies and armies use of your roads and ports on our way to Constantinople when the time comes?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso actually laughs—a short, warm sound of genuine amusement.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Juan, you just won me my kingdom with fifteen thousand men who marched through my roads and sailed into my ports. You ask if you may do again what you have already done? Of course. A thousand times, yes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, moving to a side table where wine and cups wait. He pours two measures of the Sicilian red and brings one to Juan.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Naples will provision your armies. Sicilian granaries will feed your soldiers. Aragonese shipyards will repair your vessels. When the hour comes and Castilian banners march east, every port from Barcelona to Taranto will open to them. This I can promise without hesitation, without condition, without consultation with any noble or council.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He raises his own cup.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: To the roads and ports of Aragón and Naples—open to the armies of Castile, now and always, for as long as our houses endure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: After drinking, Alfonso sets down his cup and his expression turns more businesslike.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: We should formalize this. A treaty of free passage and mutual support—something my nobles can see, something that binds future generations. Not unified command, but... coordinated purpose. The terms we discussed. Joint councils, shared intelligence, mutual defense, and now free passage for crusading armies. Draft it. I will sign it. And when you return to Castile, bring it before your Cortes as I will bring it before mine. Let it be known throughout Christendom that the crowns of Castile, Aragón, and Naples stand as one against the enemies of the faith.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Is there anything else you need from me before I begin the tedious work of actually ruling this kingdom you won for me?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will draft it, but a few questions. Can I include that when the sultan moves or the fight is taken to the Ottomans, Aragon and Naples contribute what they can, understanding that you will use the coming years to consolidate your kingdom?

encounters.recap: Juan outlines his long-term strategy to Alfonso: build strength in Constantinople for five years, then launch a coordinated campaign through Hungary to retake the Anastasian Wall from the Ottomans. Alfonso pledges full support, offering ports, provisions, and his personal participation when the time comes. They agree to formalize a treaty of alliance and mutual support for the coming crusade against Ottoman expansion.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: We should formalize this. A treaty of free passage and mutual support—something my nobles can see, something that binds future generations. Not unified command, but... coordinated purpose. The terms we discussed. Joint councils, shared intelligence, mutual defense, and now free passage for crusading armies.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso pauses, the wine cup halfway to his lips. He sets it down carefully.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: 'Contribute what they can,' that is... deliberately vague, is it not? I have already told you I will be there personally when the hour comes. I meant it. But putting words in a treaty that my nobles and my Cortes will read... They will ask questions. What does 'what they can' mean? Who decides what Aragón can contribute? If Naples faces rebellion, can I withhold forces? If Sicily is threatened by Tunisian pirates, must I still send ships east?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: And there is the matter of when this obligation triggers. If the Sultan attacks Constantinople, that is clear—defensive war, sacred duty, no one could object. But if you take the fight to the Ottomans... If you march through Hungary to reclaim Thrace, that is offensive war. Glorious, righteous, but offensive. My nobles will ask: are we obligated to join a war of your choosing, at a time of your choosing?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: I am not refusing. I am telling you what questions will be asked, so we can answer them in the document itself. What if we phrase it thus: Aragón and Naples commit to the defense of Constantinople and to supporting military operations against the Ottoman Empire, with contributions determined by consultation between the crowns based on the capacity of each kingdom at the time. It binds us to the cause. It promises contribution. But it preserves my judgment on what my kingdoms can spare. Does that satisfy your purpose, or do you need something more... binding?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is indeed what I had in mind. Do you have a need for me and my army now? Do they have to batter down some rebels? Or can I just go home?

encounters.recap: Juan and Alfonso negotiate the final terms of their military alliance treaty, addressing concerns about obligation triggers and contribution levels. They agree on language that commits both kingdoms to anti-Ottoman operations while preserving Alfonso's sovereignty over his military decisions.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Palazzo Caracciolo sits in the better quarter of Naples, its thick stone walls offering some relief from the July heat. Aragonese guards in Alfonso's livery flank the entrance—a gift from the King of Aragón, honoring his oath to protect Lucia as he would his own sister. You find her in a shaded courtyard, reclining on cushions beneath a lemon tree. Her pregnancy is unmistakable now—six months along, her figure transformed from the tall, slender woman who read your letter aloud in Ferrara and declared she would like to meet this king. Her dark hair is pinned loosely against the heat, and she fans herself with an ivory fan that bears the Este arms. She looks up as you enter, and her grey-green eyes sharpen with that familiar intelligence.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Ah, the conquering hero returns from his councils with kings. Is Naples secured? Have you and Alfonso divided the Mediterranean between you over wine and maps?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She shifts on the cushions, one hand resting on her swollen belly. When you ask your question, her fan stops mid-motion. She studies you for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Would I rather stay here than travel to Toledo. That is an interesting way to phrase it, my love. Not 'I need you in Toledo' or 'the kingdom requires its queen.' But what I would rather do. Are you asking because you want to know my comfort? Or because you're trying to decide whether to leave me here while you sail off to meet a Sultan?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, love! I did not expect such political calculations from you. I ask because I want to know what you want. Probably, we will stay here right? I think that's what you would want but I ask to know for sure.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's expression softens at your words, the sharpness giving way to something warmer. She sets down the fan and extends her hand toward you—an invitation to sit beside her on the cushions.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Forgive me. The heat makes me irritable, and this child makes me suspicious of everything. Your son or daughter is equally irritable, I think. They kick at all hours. What I want... I want to not travel by ship while carrying a child, if it can be avoided. The journey from Constantinople to Rhodes to Naples was... unpleasant. The surgeons say sea travel in the final months carries risk. Naples is tolerable. The palazzo is comfortable, Alfonso's guards are attentive, and the Italian physicians here trained in Salerno—the best in Christendom for matters of childbirth, or so they claim. And I confess, the thought of months in a swaying carrack, followed by weeks on Castilian roads, followed by arriving in Toledo enormous and exhausted to meet a court that has never seen their new queen... So yes. I would rather stay. Have the child here, recover my strength, and meet your kingdom as a queen should—not as a whale being carted through the gates. But what are your plans, husband? Truly?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was going to stay here with you. Unless the sultan attacks Constantinople, I will stay here with you until after the birth and you have recovered. Let Catalina play here. Sometimes I wonder how all this constant travel will affect her, always seeing new things, ships, horses, carriages... What sort of person will she become later on?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's face transforms—genuine surprise, then a warmth that reaches her eyes.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You will stay? Truly? I had prepared myself to be brave about it. To tell you that queens must endure, that Constantinople needs you, that I understood. I am relieved beyond measure that I do not have to be that noble. I have wondered the same thing. She is... what, two and a half years old? And already she has seen more of the world than most nobles see in a lifetime. Rome, Basel, Constantinople, Rhodes, Naples... She will not remember most of it, but it shapes her nonetheless. The sounds, the motion, the endless parade of new faces speaking new languages. She may become restless. The kind of woman who cannot stay in one place, who finds castle walls a prison rather than a home. Or she may crave stability above all else—having known so little of it, she may build walls around herself and never leave them. What sort of father do you want to be to her, Juan? And to this one? You are building an empire. Defending Christendom. Meeting with sultans and emperors. Where do your children fit in that vision?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will first let them develop. They are children after all. Whatever they are interested in, I will nurture that. If they want to ride, hunt, fish, fight, shoot, sail... I will let them explore this. Then as they grow older, I will put them to work for the crown. Catalina will sooner or later learn that not everything is fun play and crostatas. She will be a princess and I will probably send her on diplomatic missions. But that will depend on who she is going to be, what her talents are and also what she wants.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: That is... more thoughtful than most fathers manage. My own father—God rest him—had my marriage planned before I could walk. I was a piece on his board, nothing more. You speak of letting them discover themselves first. That is rare in a king. Catalina is sweet. She follows me around the palazzo, chattering in that mix of Castilian and Italian she's invented. She called me mama yesterday. I did not correct her, though I wonder if I should have. She does not remember Isabel, does she? She was so young when... And Fernando will never know his mother at all. Only what we tell him. I want to do right by them, Juan. Not replace Isabel—I could not even if I wished it. But I do not want them to grow up feeling... divided. Between her memory and my presence. And this one. Will they be siblings truly, or will there always be a wall between Isabel's children and mine?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont think so Lucia. Catalina considers you her mama. She is happy. Just be her mama. And let her enjoy her new brother or sister. There is a painting of Isabel in Toledo. When she grows, we will explain to her when it is time. But not yet. Lets just enjoy this time of peace and quiet until the baby is born. I will stay here for a few months. I disband the army. I await message from the sultan.

encounters.recap: Juan visits Lucia at the Palazzo Caracciolo to discuss their future plans. They decide to remain in Naples until after the birth of their child, with Juan promising to stay and disband his army. They have an intimate conversation about Catalina's acceptance of Lucia as her mother and their hopes for creating a unified family despite the complicated legacy of Juan's first wife Isabel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's expression softens completely. She leans forward—as much as her condition allows—and kisses you gently. "Then we shall have peace," she murmurs. "For a few months at least."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Castilian army disperses. Don Íñigo López de Mendoza sails with the bulk of the forces back to Castile—fifteen thousand men returning home to families, farms, and the ordinary lives of peacetime. The 200 Military Order soldiers who accompanied you from Constantinople remain as your personal guard, quartered in Naples at Alfonso's hospitality.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Letters are dispatched: to Álvaro de Luna in Toledo, informing him of Naples' resolution and your intention to remain until Lucia's delivery; to Don García López de Padilla in Granada, confirming the administration continues in your absence; to the Military Order commanders, acknowledging their soldiers' service.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso throws himself into the work of consolidating his new kingdom. You see him occasionally—shared dinners, brief consultations—but he is consumed with the business of transforming from heir to king.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Three weeks after the Battle of Aversa, a Venetian trading vessel arrives in Naples harbor bearing a passenger of note: a Ottoman diplomatic secretary named Hamza Bey, accompanied by four attendants and a document bearing the tughra of Sultan Murad II. The man requests an audience with the King of Castile.

encounters.recap: Juan disbands the Castilian army in Naples, sending fifteen thousand men home to Castile while keeping his 200 Military Order guards. He remains in Naples to await Lucia's delivery. Three weeks later, Ottoman diplomat Hamza Bey arrives bearing a message from Sultan Murad II, requesting audience with the King of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Three weeks after the Battle of Aversa, a Venetian trading vessel arrives in Naples harbor bearing a passenger of note: a Ottoman diplomatic secretary named Hamza Bey, accompanied by four attendants and a document bearing the tughra of Sultan Murad II. The man requests an audience with the King of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You receive Hamza Bey in a modest audience chamber at Castel Nuovo. As he enters, something flickers in his expression—recognition. It is the same man. He is older than you remembered from those tense weeks in Constantinople—the Ottoman observer who watched your knights drill, who counted your ships, who reported everything to Edirne. The man whose eyes widened when you greeted him in Arabic, breaking every expectation he had of Latin kings. The man you expelled from Constantinople after the Emperor signed the decree naming you Defensor Romaniae.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: As-salamu alaykum, King of Castile. We meet again. Under different circumstances. When you expelled me from Constantinople, I told my master that I had encountered something new. A Latin king who speaks the tongue of the Prophet—peace be upon him—and who acts rather than merely talks. The Sultan was... intrigued. Your letter intrigued him further.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: His Majesty agrees that a meeting may be possible. But he has questions first. You write of understanding. You write of delivering tribute. But you garrison Constantinople with knights and name yourself Defensor. You repair walls the treaty forbade the Greeks to repair. You train militia. You cast cannons. My master is patient. But he is not foolish. So he sends me to ask plainly, king to king's servant: What do you want? Peace? Or merely time to prepare for war?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Right now, the city of Constantinople is owned by the Byzantine empire. And me and the Latins intend to improve trade through this important port. And defense is a natural way to secure this investment. What worth is an investment is someone else can just walk in and take it? Constantinople is surrounded on all sides by vast lands owned by the sultan. We pose no threat to him, we merely seek to be able to defend ourselves. The Byzantines have been scraping the tribute together. Now, with investment from the latins, the sultan can be assured tribute reliably. Is the sultan making plans to attack and wage war on the Byzantines?

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan makes many plans. He is the Shadow of God on Earth, Commander of the Faithful. His responsibilities stretch from the Danube to Anatolia. Constantinople is... one concern among many. But you must understand, King of Castile, that my master has heard such words before. 'We seek only to defend ourselves.' 'We mean no threat.' The Venetians said this when they bought Thessalonica. They fortified it. They garrisoned it. They spoke of trade and investment. And when the city fell, Venice sued for peace within a year and resumed trading as if nothing had happened. Seven thousand souls enslaved, and the Venetians counted their coins.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: You are not Venice. This my master understands. You conquered Granada. You do not merely talk of holy war—you make holy war. You speak Arabic and ask questions about the Prophet, peace be upon him, yet you drove the Muslims from Iberia after eight hundred years. So when you say you seek only defense and reliable tribute... my master wonders. Is this the wolf who has eaten his fill and now wishes to sleep? Or the wolf who rests before the next hunt?

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: The Sultan proposes this: a meeting on neutral ground, as you requested. The island of Tenedos, at the mouth of the Dardanelles. Neither Ottoman nor Byzantine territory—held by Venice, who will guarantee safe passage for both parties. Equal guards—fifty men each. No more. But before my master commits to this meeting, he wishes to know: What would you discuss? Trade arrangements, you mentioned. Tribute delivery. These are matters for secretaries, not kings. What does the King of Castile wish to say to the Sultan of the Ottomans that requires they meet face to face?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will not deny that there is much reason for hostile relations between our people. The Byzantines still consider the old borders of their empire to be the rightfull state of things. And I know that many a sultan has been eying Constantinople hungrily. Right now, there is no reason for conflict. Trade benefits both parties and that is what I want to discuss. But most of all. I want to meet him. If there is an incident or conflict. I want to know the man. Who he is and how he will react. He has done things a great ruler would do. I want to look him in the eye and shake his hand. And I feel like the feeling is mutual. The arrangement is agreed. As you can see my wife is with child and I will be able to visit next year.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: You are... remarkably honest, King of Castile. Most rulers would speak only of eternal friendship and mutual benefit. You speak of wanting to know the man you might one day face across a battlefield. My master will appreciate this. He has little patience for flattery and less for deception. The feeling is mutual. When I returned to Edirne and described you—the Arabic, the questions about faith, the way you moved through Constantinople as if you already owned it—the Sultan listened more carefully than I have seen him listen in years. He said... 'This one is dangerous. I would like to meet him.'

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: Next year, then. Spring, perhaps, when the seas are calm and your child is safely delivered. I will carry your acceptance to my master. The details—exact dates, the number of ships, the arrangements with Venice—these can be negotiated through intermediaries over the winter.

exchanges.speaker: hamza_bey
exchanges.text: One more thing, King of Castile. My master asked me to observe you. To assess what manner of man you are. I will tell him this: You conquered Granada not through cruelty but through strategy. You took Constantinople's loyalty not through force but through generosity. You speak of defense, but you build alliances that could threaten our borders from Hungary to the Mediterranean. I will tell him you are exactly as dangerous as he suspected. And that you would make either a worthy enemy or a valuable... arrangement. Ma'a salama, King of Castile. Until Tenedos.

encounters.recap: Hamza Bey, the Ottoman envoy Juan previously expelled from Constantinople, arrives in Naples bearing Sultan Murad II's response. Through careful diplomatic exchanges, they negotiate terms for a future meeting on the neutral island of Tenedos, with both rulers expressing mutual respect and wariness. Juan's honest admission of wanting to know his potential adversary personally impresses the Ottoman diplomat, who reports that the Sultan finds Juan 'dangerous' but worthy of meeting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council convenes in a modest chamber at the Palazzo Caracciolo—not the grandeur of Toledo's alcázar, but serviceable. The summer heat is tempered by sea breezes through open windows. Your resources in Naples are limited. The great machinery of Castilian government—Álvaro de Luna, the royal chancery, the treasury officials—remains in Toledo, months away by sea. What you have is a traveling king's skeleton court.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has met with the Ottoman envoy. What do we face?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Listen. I have been named defensor and have negotiated attractive measures for latins who want to move to Constantinople. They can buy houses cheap, trade and work will pick up. Rights will be respected and we are about to start taking land back from the Ottomans. Crusade has been called and the Greeks have declared Apokatastasis. Any noble who fights for this cause gets titles. Right now, a noble who contributes about 200 men can win himself a ducal title. All the rights are signed into law. There is a muster and we count the number of men who fight this year. How more you contribute, the more titles you get. How can we best attract nobles and traders willing to settle in the city?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of attracting settlers. But we must ask: who do we wish to attract, and what do they fear? The opportunity is extraordinary—I grant this. Ducal titles for two hundred men? In Italy, such titles cost fortunes and take generations to acquire. But Constantinople is far. The Turk surrounds it. Men have heard of Thessalonica—seven thousand enslaved, the city sacked. They will ask: why should I risk my family, my fortune, my life, when the Sultan might simply take it all? The terms matter less than the confidence. Men must believe Constantinople will stand.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Don Bernat speaks true. Soldiers I can find—there are always men willing to fight for pay and glory. But settlers? Men who bring wives, children, gold to invest? They need to believe they will live to enjoy what they build. The walls must hold. The garrison must be strong. Word must spread that Constantinople is defended, not merely occupied.

exchanges.speaker: martin_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the Church is a powerful instrument for such matters. The crusade has been proclaimed. If His Holiness could be persuaded to grant... perhaps not plenary indulgence, but significant spiritual rewards for those who settle in defense of Christendom—not merely fight, but stay—the preaching networks of the mendicant orders could spread word to every parish in Europe. There are also the younger sons. Every noble house has them—men of good blood with no inheritance, no prospects. A title in Constantinople is better than nothing in Castile or Aragon or Italy.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are all thinking like men. Nobles and merchants do not make decisions alone. They have wives. Mothers. Sisters who whisper in their ears. If you want settlers, you must make Constantinople a place women will agree to go. Not just walls and soldiers—churches, markets, physicians, society. A noble wife must believe she can raise her children there, attend mass in a proper cathedral, find suitable marriages for her daughters. Write to the wives. Or better—find women who have already gone and returned safely. Let them speak of what Constantinople offers. A man may dream of titles, but he will not move his family into a war camp.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: There is also the question of where to recruit. Italy is obvious—Venice, Genoa, Florence all have men seeking opportunity, and they know the Eastern trade. But they also have old grievances with the Greeks. Ferrara, Mantua, the smaller states—fewer grievances, more hunger. And Aragon, of course. King Alfonso could be persuaded to encourage settlement if it serves his interests in the Eastern Mediterranean. What channels does Your Majesty wish to pursue? Church networks? Merchant guilds? Direct appeals to noble houses? All require different approaches—and different resources.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was thinking more about just making the opportunity public and let people talk about it themself. But if no one knows about the arrangements and the opportunity, then they will not come.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You speak of letting the river find its own course. But first, you must dig the channel.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: The opportunity is remarkable. But Your Majesty is correct—if men do not know of it, they cannot act upon it. The question becomes: how do we ensure the news spreads widely and accurately? Rumors spread on their own, but they distort. By the time word of Constantinople reaches a second son in Salamanca, it may have transformed into fantasy or nightmare. We need... a proclamation. Something official. Something that can be copied, read aloud in market squares, posted on church doors.

exchanges.speaker: martin_de_cordoba
exchanges.text: The Church already has such networks, Your Majesty. When His Holiness proclaimed the crusade, copies went to every bishop, every cathedral chapter, every monastery. The same mechanism could carry word of these settlement terms. A papal letter encouraging faithful Christians to settle in defense of Constantinople—this would reach places royal proclamations never could. The mendicant orders especially. Franciscans and Dominicans preach in every town and village. If they speak of this opportunity from the pulpit...

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Proclamations are well and good, but men believe what they see. When the first settlers return with stories of success—when a landless knight writes home that he now holds a title and a house—that is when others will follow. The first wave is always the hardest. After that, success breeds success.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Then we need both. The proclamation to plant the seed. And the stories to make it grow. Is there anyone already in Constantinople who could write such letters? Someone whose word would be trusted back home? A knight from a known family, a merchant from a respected guild? And what of those who have already committed? The knights of the Military Orders, the nobles who pledged men—do their families know what they stand to gain? A mother who learns her son may become a duke will speak of nothing else at every gathering she attends.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_de_centelles
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of the Italian merchant republics. Venice and Genoa already have quarters in Constantinople—they know the city, they know the trade. If their merchants begin speaking of new opportunities, new legal protections, favorable terms... word spreads through commercial networks faster than any proclamation. But Venice and Genoa are rivals. Favor one too openly and the other grows hostile. Perhaps... perhaps we approach the smaller Italian states first. Ferrara, Mantua, Florence. Let them establish themselves before the great powers realize what they are missing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There are already Latins living in Constantinople who will move out of the quarters and will expand their business and invest. We can report on developments in the city. Not favor anyone, just the reality of how the investments are panning out. But mainly, lets see if we can use the church to distribute the opportunities for christians who are not afraid and want to fight the good fight. And we will address women as well as men. A proclamation that can be read in every church. And we make it clear that the city is now well-defended and that the defensor will protect them. That there is a risk involved but that a christian will be rewarded for having faith.

encounters.recap: Juan convenes a council to plan recruitment for Constantinople settlers. His advisors debate strategy: Bernat emphasizes addressing fears about Ottoman threats, Lucia insists on appealing to women and families, Martín suggests using church networks, and Fernán stresses the need for early success stories. Juan decides to pursue a church-based proclamation addressing both men and women, emphasizing faith, protection, and honest reporting of opportunities.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council looks to you. The outlines of a strategy are forming: Official proclamation — documenting the terms, to be copied and distributed Church networks — papal endorsement, mendicant preaching Personal letters — from those already committed, to families back home Merchant channels — through Italian trading networks Early success stories — letting the first settlers become recruiters What approach does Juan wish to prioritize?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There are already Latins living in Constantinople who will move out of the quarters and will expand their business and invest. We can report on developments in the city. Not favor anyone, just the reality of how the investments are panning out. But mainly, lets see if we can use the church to distribute the opportunities for christians who are not afraid and want to fight the good fight. And we will adress women as well as men. A proclamation that can be read in every church. And we make it clear that the city is now well-defended and that the defensor will protect them. That there is a risk involved but that a christian will be rewarded for having faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council murmurs approval. Brother Martín is already reaching for parchment and quill.

exchanges.speaker: brother_martin
exchanges.text: A proclamation through Church channels—this is wise, Your Majesty. The faithful trust what they hear from the pulpit. And if we frame this not merely as opportunity, but as calling... The crusade already has spiritual weight. Settlement in defense of Christendom becomes an act of faith, not merely commerce.

exchanges.speaker: brother_martin
exchanges.text: We address both men and women. We speak of families building new lives in a city restored to Christ's service. We acknowledge the risk—honestly, as Your Majesty says—but we frame it as the risk all Christians take when they choose faith over fear.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: Good. But be specific about what women will find there. Churches where they may worship. Markets where they may buy familiar goods. The promise of law and order—that their homes will be protected, their children safe. Women do not fear risk if they believe their sacrifice has meaning. But they will not follow husbands into chaos.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: And speak of the future. Children born in Constantinople will inherit what their parents build. Titles pass to sons and daughters. This is not adventure—it is legacy.

exchanges.speaker: don_bernat
exchanges.text: The neutral reporting on developments—this is shrewd. No favoritism, no promises that cannot be kept. Simply: here is what is happening. Here is what the Venetian merchant built. Here is what the Aragonese knight received. Let the facts speak. Perhaps quarterly reports? Sent through the same Church channels? Men will wait for news before committing—give them news worth waiting for.

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: The defense must be emphasized. Men will ask: what stops the Turk from simply taking everything? The answer must be clear—seven hundred knights of the Military Orders hold the walls. The Hospitallers of Rhodes are committed. The Defensor has bound Castile, Aragón, and Naples to Constantinople's protection. This is not a city waiting to fall. This is a city preparing to grow.

exchanges.speaker: brother_martin
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, shall I draft this proclamation now? We have the key elements: The opportunity: land, titles, legal protections, trade rights The defense: Military Orders, the Defensor's commitment, allied kingdoms The spiritual dimension: service to Christendom, faith over fear The audience: men and women, families seeking legacy The honesty: risk acknowledged, but framed as Christian courage If we draft it here, Don Bernat can review the political implications, and Her Majesty can ensure we speak properly to women's concerns. Then we seek papal endorsement to distribute through Church networks.

exchanges.speaker: brother_martin
exchanges.text: We will need His Holiness's approval for this to be read from pulpits. Will Pope Eugenius support such a proclamation?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I can send even more military order soldiers to Constantinople. Fernan, do you think the military orders can support 2000 soldiers in Constantinople? During the crusades they supplier 4500...

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I can speak to what I've seen, though the Masters themselves would know their true capacity better than I. During the Granada campaign, the three Orders fielded their full strength—Santiago brought two thousand, Calatrava fifteen hundred, Alcántara one thousand. That was everything they had, and it strained them. Men, horses, supplies—all committed for two years of hard campaigning.

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: Now they've returned to their territories. The crusade service is complete. They're recovering, rebuilding, tending to their estates and commanderies. Asking them to maintain two thousand men permanently in Constantinople... that's different from a campaign. A campaign ends. A garrison is forever.

exchanges.speaker: don_bernat
exchanges.text: There's also the question of distance. Granada was Castilian territory—supply lines were short, reinforcements close. Constantinople is months away by sea. Every man stationed there must be fed, armed, paid, and rotated eventually. The cost of maintaining a thousand men in Constantinople is perhaps three times what it would cost in Iberia.

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: Seven hundred are there now under Sotomayor. The Orders could likely sustain twelve to fifteen hundred without breaking themselves—rotating companies, perhaps three hundred men cycling home each year while fresh troops arrive. Two thousand permanently? That would require the Pope's authority to compel it, or significant crown support to offset the cost. The Masters would resist depleting their home garrisons entirely.

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: Unless... Your Majesty intends to change how the Orders operate? The papal decree gave you authority over them. If Constantinople becomes their primary purpose rather than an obligation alongside their Iberian duties...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will write them to bring their number in Constantinople to 1000. And to establish commanderies there. When I come back to Iberia, I will indeed give them a new mission charter binding them to the Apokatastasis. After Grenada, new lands to reclaim from the infidel. A new holy cause.

exchanges.speaker: brother_martin
exchanges.text: A new holy cause. The Reconquista complete, and now the Orders turn eastward. Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara—no longer defenders of a frontier that no longer exists, but swords of Christendom against the greater enemy. Your Majesty, this is... this is what the Orders were founded for. Before they became landlords and tax collectors. You would restore them to their purpose.

exchanges.speaker: captain_fernan
exchanges.text: Two hundred eighty-five more men to bring the garrison to one thousand. That's achievable—a company from each Order, rotated from their Iberian holdings. The commanderies in Constantinople... That's clever. Once they have property there, permanent presence, they're invested. It's no longer a distant obligation but their own land to defend.

exchanges.speaker: don_bernat
exchanges.text: King Alfonso will be interested in this development. Aragón has its own Military Orders—the Order of Montesa, small but capable. If Castilian Orders establish themselves in Constantinople, Aragonese knights may wish to follow. This serves the alliance. Iberian military presence in the Eastern Mediterranean, bound by holy oaths rather than merely treaties.

exchanges.speaker: don_bernat
exchanges.text: The Masters, though—they are proud men. They will accept Your Majesty's authority, as the papal decree commands. But how you present this matters. If it seems punishment or exile, they will resist in subtle ways. If it seems honor and holy mission...

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: You are not merely garrisoning a city. You are building an institution. The Orders bound to Constantinople become your Orders in a way they never were in Iberia, where they answer to Pope and tradition as much as crown. When you write this charter, my love, you are writing the future of Christian power in the East. Choose your words carefully.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: And the Masters should be present when you announce this new mission. Let them stand beside you, not receive letters from afar. They must feel they are partners in this holy cause, not servants receiving commands.

exchanges.speaker: brother_martin
exchanges.text: Shall I draft the letter to the Masters requesting the additional troops, Your Majesty? And perhaps... an outline of the new mission charter, to be refined when you return to Castile?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Command them to bring the number in the city to 1000 and to start establishing a permanent presence there. Also note that I will discuss their new charter when I return. Also, draft the proclamation that is to be spread through the churches.

roll.outcome: Extraordinary Transformation. Over 5,000 settlers arrive—enough to meaningfully restore Constantinople's population. Entire extended families relocate. Italian city-states compete for trading privileges. The Military Orders petition to make Constantinople their primary headquarters. Greeks and Latins begin intermarrying. The city buzzes with construction, commerce, and hope. Christendom speaks of the Apokatastasis as something real, not merely a dream. The Sultan takes notice.

encounters.recap: Juan finalizes strategy for settling Constantinople through Church-distributed proclamations targeting Christian families. He orders Military Orders to expand to 1,000 men and establish permanent commanderies, planning to bind them to the Apokatastasis with new charters. The settlement campaign achieves extraordinary success, with over 5,000 settlers transforming the city and establishing it as a vibrant Christian center that draws notice across Christendom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council concludes with Brother Martín gathering his notes, Don Bernat offering to review the proclamation's political language, and Captain Fernán departing to arrange couriers for the Military Orders.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia catches your eye as the others file out. She remains seated, one hand on her belly, watching you with that sharp gaze.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You plant seeds so easily. I wonder if you know what forests you are growing.

roll.outcome: Extraordinary Transformation. Something catches fire. The proclamation combines with Juan's reputation, the crusade fervor, and genuine opportunity to create a movement. Over 5,000 settlers arrive—enough to meaningfully restore Constantinople's population. Entire extended families relocate. Italian city-states compete for trading privileges. The Military Orders petition to make Constantinople their primary headquarters. Greeks and Latins begin intermarrying. The city buzzes with construction, commerce, and hope. Christendom speaks of the Apokatastasis as something real, not merely a dream. The Sultan takes notice.

encounters.recap: The settlement proclamation campaign achieves extraordinary success. Over 5,000 settlers will arrive in Constantinople over the next two years, transforming the city from decline to visible growth. The Military Orders seek to relocate headquarters there, Italian city-states compete for trading rights, and the Apokatastasis becomes a symbol of Christian renewal across Europe.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Naples bakes under the August sun. Juan finds himself in an unfamiliar situation—a king with nothing urgent to do. Letters have been sent; responses will take weeks to arrive. The army has disbanded and sailed home. Alfonso is consumed with the business of claiming his inheritance, meeting with Calabrian lords, reorganizing the administration Queen Joanna neglected in her final years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan corresponds with his officials. A letter to Álvaro confirming the Naples resolution and the Ottoman envoy's visit. A letter to Don García López de Padilla in Granada, inquiring about the administration. A letter to Fray Hernando in Basel, asking about the Council's mood.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The replies, when they come, are reassuring in their mundanity. Castile is stable. Granada is quiet. The Council debates endlessly but has not erupted into schism. The world turns without requiring Juan's immediate attention.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He explores Naples—the great Castel Nuovo, the crowded harbor, the ancient churches. He dines with Alfonso when the King of Aragón can spare an evening from his duties. They speak of strategy, of family, of the future they are building together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Mostly, he waits. Lucia grows larger and more uncomfortable as the weeks pass. She complains about the heat, about the food, about the inadequacy of Neapolitan physicians compared to those she might have had in Ferrara or Toledo. Juan has learned that these complaints are how she manages fear—by focusing on irritations she can name rather than dangers she cannot control.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence from the wider world is, in its way, a blessing. No news is good news. The crises that might have been—Ottoman aggression, Castilian rebellion, Neapolitan treachery—do not materialize. September arrives. The heat begins to break. And Lucia's time draws near.

roll.outcome: Quiet Waiting: The summer passes without significant incident. Juan corresponds with his officials, explores Naples, builds his relationship with Alfonso. The world grants him a rare gift: peace.

encounters.recap: During the late summer of 1434, Juan experiences a rare period of calm while awaiting Lucia's delivery in Naples. With no urgent crises demanding attention, he corresponds with officials, explores the city, and strengthens his alliance with Alfonso. The peaceful weeks prove to be an unexpected blessing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The pains begin in the small hours of the morning, September 14th. Juan is woken by a servant's urgent knock—the Queen's waters have broken. He rises to find the Palazzo Caracciolo already stirring, candles lit in windows, midwives hurrying through corridors. The Salerno physicians have been summoned; they arrive within the hour, grave-faced men carrying leather bags of instruments Juan does not wish to examine.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He is not permitted in the birthing chamber. This is women's work, the midwives tell him firmly. He may wait in the antechamber. He may pace. He may pray. But he may not interfere. So Juan waits.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hours pass with agonizing slowness. He hears Lucia's cries through the heavy door—at first controlled, then ragged, then sounds he has never heard a human make. He paces. He prays. He sends servants for updates and receives only "proceeding normally" and "these things take time."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Dawn comes. The cries continue. Captain Fernán appears at some point, says something about standing watch, positions himself by the door. Juan barely registers his presence. Brother Martín arrives to pray with him; the Latin words wash over Juan without meaning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Mid-morning. The cries grow worse, then suddenly stop. Juan's heart freezes. Then—a different sound. Thin, warbling, unmistakable. A baby's cry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chief physician emerges an hour later, wiping his hands on a cloth. His expression is tired but satisfied.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "Your Majesty. The Queen has delivered successfully. A difficult labor, but within normal bounds for a first birth. She is exhausted and will require rest—two to three weeks before she should be moved, longer before she regains her full strength. She is asking for you."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds Lucia propped against pillows, her dark hair plastered to her forehead with sweat, her grey-green eyes shadowed with exhaustion. She looks like she has fought a battle—because she has. But she is alive. She is whole. And in her arms...

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Well, that was unpleasant. I hope you appreciate what I endure for this dynasty of yours.

roll.outcome: Normal Delivery - The birth proceeds as births do—painful, frightening, exhausting, but ultimately successful. The labor lasts eight to twelve hours. Recovery takes two to three weeks.

encounters.recap: Lucia d'Este delivers her first child after a normal but difficult labor lasting through the night. Juan waits anxiously outside the birthing chamber while she endures hours of pain. Both mother and child survive the delivery, though Lucia requires weeks of recovery.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She looks up as he enters. A weak smile crosses her face.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Well, that was unpleasant. I hope you appreciate what I endure for this dynasty of yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia shifts against the pillows, wincing slightly at the movement. The exhaustion is written in every line of her face—dark circles under her eyes, pallor beneath her olive complexion, trembling in her hands. But those grey-green eyes, when they meet yours, still carry their familiar sharpness.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: How am I? I feel as though a horse trampled me from the inside. The physicians assure me this is normal. I have doubts about their definition of normal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She adjusts the small bundle in her arms, and for the first time you see the face of your child clearly. Tiny, red, wrinkled—as all newborns are—with a wisp of dark hair and eyes squeezed shut against the unfamiliar world.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: A daughter. I hope you are not disappointed. I know kings prefer sons.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She looks down at the infant, and something in her expression shifts—a tenderness you have not seen before, cutting through the exhaustion and the sharp wit.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: She came into this world screaming her displeasure. The midwives say that is a good sign—strong lungs, strong will. I suspect she will be trouble. She is already very demanding about when she wishes to eat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia looks up at you, suddenly vulnerable beneath the bravado.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Have you thought of a name?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I was thinking of an Italian name. She is born of an Italian mother in Italy. What are you thinking of?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's eyebrows rise slightly—a flicker of surprise, then something softer. Gratitude, perhaps, that he would offer this.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: An Italian name. My mother was Costanza. She died when I was young—I barely remember her face, only her voice singing to me. But perhaps that is too melancholy a legacy to burden a child with.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She shifts the baby gently, thinking.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: There is Beatrice—a good Ferrarese name. The poets have made it immortal through Dante. And there was a Beatrice d'Este who was Duchess of Milan, a woman of some renown. Though the Visconti might take it as a pointed reminder of Este claims.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She considers further.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Bianca is simple and beautiful. Eleonora has strength to it—there have been queens by that name. Francesca... Too common.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia looks up at you, her exhaustion momentarily forgotten in the contemplation.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: What sounds right to you, when you look at her? Beatrice? Costanza? Eleonora? Or perhaps she will tell us herself, when she opens her eyes and shows us who she is.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The baby stirs, makes a small sound of complaint, and settles again.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: She has opinions already. Definitely trouble.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Welcome to the world Bianca of Castille. You are a wonder of God. And we love you very much.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: I take Catalina and show her her baby sister.

encounters.recap: Juan's second daughter Bianca is born to Lucia Visconti in Naples. Despite the exhaustion of childbirth, Lucia maintains her wit while showing tender vulnerability. They discuss Italian names before settling on Bianca, and Juan introduces the newborn to her sister Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: Bianca is simple and beautiful. Eleonora has strength to it—there have been queens by that name. Francesca... Too common. What sounds right to you, when you look at her? Beatrice? Costanza? Eleonora? Or perhaps she will tell us herself, when she opens her eyes and shows us who she is.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The baby stirs, makes a small sound of complaint, and settles again.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: She has opinions already. Definitely trouble.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Welcome to the world Bianca of Castille. You are a wonder of God. And we love you very much.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the adjoining chamber with Doña Beatriz, the Portuguese lady-in-waiting who has cared for her since Isabel's death. The little girl is playing with wooden blocks, stacking them into precarious towers and knocking them down with delighted shrieks. She looks up as you enter, and her face transforms.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Papa, I builded a castle. It falled down.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I saw. It was a very good castle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Where is Mama?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Mama is resting. She worked very hard today. But she wants to see you. Catalina, do you remember what we talked about? About the baby in Mama's belly? The baby came out today. You have a little sister now.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: A sister?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. Her name is Bianca. Would you like to meet her?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You carry Catalina into the chamber. Lucia looks up, her exhaustion momentarily brightened by the sight of her stepdaughter.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: Catalina, tesoro. Come see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You bring Catalina close to the bed. She peers at the bundle in Lucia's arms with deep suspicion, as only a toddler can.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: It's small.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: She is small. She just arrived. She will grow bigger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina leans closer, studying the wrinkled red face with intense scrutiny. Bianca's eyes flutter open briefly—unfocused, newborn-dark—then close again.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Why is she all red?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: Babies are red when they're new. You were red too, when you were born.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No I wasn't.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia catches your eye, suppressing a smile despite her exhaustion. Catalina reaches out a tentative finger toward Bianca's face. Lucia gently redirects her hand to touch the baby's tiny fist instead. Bianca's fingers curl reflexively around Catalina's fingertip. Catalina's eyes go wide.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: She grabbed me!

exchanges.speaker: lucia_caracciolo
exchanges.text: She likes you. She knows you're her big sister.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina considers this for a long moment, her expression shifting through several emotions too complex for her years. Then she looks up at you with profound seriousness.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I will teach her about castles. When she's bigger.

encounters.recap: Juan introduces two-year-old Catalina to her newborn half-sister Bianca. Despite initial suspicion about the small, red baby, Catalina's protective instincts emerge when Bianca grasps her finger, and she solemnly promises to teach her sister about building castles when she grows bigger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The journey has progressed well thus far. The sea crossing from Naples to Valencia passed without incident, and the royal party has been traveling overland through Castile for several days. The winter air is crisp but not bitter; the roads are passable. It is Doña Beatriz who notices first.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, Catalina has developed a cough. It started this morning—I thought it was just the cold air, but it has persisted.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: It does not seem serious. She is eating well, playing normally, no fever that I can detect. But with the infant and the Queen...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the inn's common room, playing with a wooden horse one of the soldiers carved for her. She looks up at your approach, smiles, and then coughs—a small, wet sound, followed by a sniffle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, look. It's a fast horse. Like yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She seems entirely herself—bright-eyed, energetic, unbothered by the cough that punctuates her chatter. The party is perhaps five or six days from Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Catalina! Love. For a few days you will stay with papa and we play a game that we must stay away from the baby and mama. When they come close we must run away ok? Shall we play?

roll.outcome: Minor illness affects Catalina with cough and congestion, very mild severity

encounters.recap: During the journey home to Toledo, young Catalina develops a mild cough and congestion. Though not serious, Juan takes precautionary measures to keep her separated from baby Bianca and recovering Lucia by turning isolation into a playful game.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the inn's common room, playing with a wooden horse one of the soldiers carved for her. She looks up at your approach, smiles, and then coughs—a small, wet sound, followed by a sniffle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, look. It's a fast horse. Like yours.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She seems entirely herself—bright-eyed, energetic, unbothered by the cough that punctuates her chatter. The party is perhaps five or six days from Toledo.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hi Catalina! Love. For a few days you will stay with papa and we play a game that we must stay away from the baby and mama. When they come close we must run away ok? Shall we play?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: A running away game? I'm good at running! But why we run from Mama and baby? Is it like hide and seek? Do they try to find us? Do we hide?

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: I can have Catalina's things moved to the adjoining chamber, Your Majesty. She can travel in the second carriage with myself and the guards. I will keep her entertained. Shall I inform the Queen? She will worry if Catalina suddenly avoids her without explanation.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Papa. Can the horse play too? He wants to run away also.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I stay with Catalina the coming days and play to be her horse. Then we walk together to Lucia and run away the moment she moves a bit closer to us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days that follow are unlike any Juan has experienced as king. He gets down on hands and knees on the cold floor of roadside inns while Catalina clambers onto his back, shrieking with delight. The King of Castile, Defensor Romaniae, conqueror of Granada—reduced to a child's steed, complete with neighing sounds that make Catalina dissolve into giggles.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Faster, horse! Faster!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Each evening, they approach Lucia's chamber. They peek around the doorframe. Lucia sits in a chair by the fire, Bianca in her arms. She looks up, sees them, and her face softens with understanding.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Oh, there you are. I've been looking for you two—

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: RUN!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They flee down the corridor, her laughter echoing off the stone walls. Juan scoops her up and gallops away, her small arms wrapped around his neck, coughing and giggling simultaneously. Behind them, he hears Lucia's voice, warm with amusement.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I'll catch you eventually!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On the third evening, Lucia catches Juan's eye from across the room while Catalina is distracted with her wooden horse. She mouths silently: Thank you. She understands. The game that keeps her daughter happy is also the game that keeps Bianca safe. By the fifth day, the cough has faded to an occasional sniffle.

encounters.recap: When Catalina develops a minor cough during the journey to Toledo, Juan creates a playful quarantine game where they pretend to run away from Lucia and baby Bianca. Over five days, Juan plays horse for his daughter while maintaining distance from the others, successfully preventing the illness from spreading to the infant while keeping Catalina entertained and happy.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The towers of the Alcázar rise against a pale winter sky as the royal procession approaches the city gates. Word has traveled ahead—crowds line the streets despite the cold, cheering for the king who left to save Constantinople and returns with a new queen and a new princess. But Juan's thoughts are not on the crowds.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro de Luna waits in the great courtyard, his weathered face breaking into a rare smile as Juan dismounts. Behind him stands the household staff, the guards, the officials who have kept Castile running in his absence. And there, held in the arms of a wet nurse, is Fernando. Juan's son. Fourteen months old now. Born the day Isabel died—the son Juan has seen only once, at his baptism, when the boy was barely two months old.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando has grown. He is no longer the tiny, swaddled bundle Juan remembers. He has dark hair like his mother, and her eyes—Isabel's eyes, the same eyes Catalina carries. He looks at Juan with the open curiosity of a child encountering a stranger. Because that is what Juan is to him. A stranger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia hangs back, Bianca in her arms, understanding without being told that this moment belongs to Juan and his firstborn son. Catalina tugs at Juan's hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa, who is that baby?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is your brother, mija. Fernando. Do you remember? I told you about him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina studies the boy with the same suspicious scrutiny she applied to Bianca.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He's bigger than Bianca.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: He is older. He has been waiting here for us to come home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan approaches the wet nurse and she curtsies, offering Fernando to him. The boy looks uncertain, glancing back at the only caregivers he has known. His lower lip trembles. Juan takes his son in his arms for only the second time. Fernando stares at him—this large stranger with the tired eyes and the travel-worn clothes. For a long moment, neither moves. Then Fernando reaches out a small hand and touches Juan's beard, fascinated by the texture.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. That's Papa. He's nice. He's a good horse.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando blinks, processing this information. His hand remains tangled in Juan's beard. Lucia steps forward now, Bianca stirring in her arms.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Fernando. I am Lucia. I am... I am going to help take care of you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She does not say mother. She will not claim that title uninvited. But her eyes are gentle as she looks at the boy who will never know the woman who died bringing him into the world. The four of them stand together in the courtyard of the Alcázar—Juan holding Fernando, Lucia holding Bianca, Catalina clinging to Juan's leg. A family. Broken and remade. Marked by loss. But together at last.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro clears his throat softly.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
